title: `datalad install` is installing an older commit, why?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Issue asks a question rather than reporting a problem

body:
#### What is the problem?
I am encountering an issue I can't find a reason for. I have a nested structure of datasets, say parent A with children B and C. When I install A recursively (`datalad install -r --source /PATH/TO/A`) I end up with an older copy of A which does not contain some of the subdatasets (say, missing C which was added at a later commit). I can't understand why is this happening, any idea?

As a result, also the subdatasets are outdated, example below:

```
### original source location
[dorian@mri STUDY1]$ git submodule
+5c62264b5d7ebe119deeeb2a08ebc8f1d49afd63 data/bids (v0.9-GoodImages)
 8a3f036fdbd18092661d4fe16071d3f962627ab5 data/processed (v0.5)
### new install location
[dorian@mri STUDY1]$ cd /DATA/dorian/datasets/STUDY1/
[dorian@mri STUDY1]$ git submodule
 2e335c4720e60b0408f9496fb51b23a6dbb1e521 data/bids (v0.5~22)
 8c38621bd1925baabd69953e2c114b438eda8ab5 data/processed (v0.5~7)
```

#### What steps will reproduce the problem?
Hopefully this does not need a reproducible example.

#### What version of DataLad are you using (run `datalad --version`)? On what operating system (consider running `datalad wtf`)?   
`datalad 0.14.0`

#### Is there anything else that would be useful to know in this context?
No

#### Have you had any success using DataLad before? (to assess your expertise/prior luck.  We would welcome your testimonial additions to https://github.com/datalad/datalad/wiki/Testimonials as well)
Yes
